page.title: 07A glimpse of Thurlow
page.content: The visual impression is of comfortable rural charm; every square foot is cared for ; fields and roadsides well tended and houses and gardens immaculate. Little Thurlow's church of St Peter dates mainly from the 14th & 15th centuries. Built of flint and stone with its tower decorated with chequer patterned battlements, it features some unusual 'spiders web' windows above the aisles. Otherwise the oldest buildings are the fine millow Elizabethan brick almshouses and free school given to the village in 1614. The smock mill overlooking the village has outlived 11 of the 13 once visible from its top; worked until 1937 it was restored by the estate owner in 1962 making a fine landmark. Little Thurlow features a small triangular green, formerly an animal pound, ad a shallow ford.
